Anyway, I don't want to bash the movie completely so I will leave my comments at "I was highly disappointed". However, I cannot say that all is lost as there is no way the second one will be worse, it can only get better. So things are looking up (only a little though).

In summary, I give this movie a 6 out of ten. This is based on my scale where a 5 is tolerable and a rating any lower is how badly you want the movie to end while watching it (4 being "I'm going to go to the washroom and hopefully it will be better or over when I get back" 3 being "ok time to wrap it up", 2 being oh god just finish the freakin' movie, 1 being "shoot me. shoot me now, right in the head, oh god, please shoot me".)

So I say, go see this movie if you intend on seeing the second one, but my recommendation is to rent it when it comes out.

title: Not what I expected
review:
The movie had great special effects, and some very talented actors, but the plot was lacking. Whith characters with this many powers, they took too long for them to figure out that they had them, and then acted like they did not know how to use them in the least. There were so many things that they could have done to make this a great film, but they just did not do it. I am not sure if they just tried too hard to show the history, or to give some background for the plot. I was just let down.

The Villain was not anywhere near as strong as he was in the comic books. (For those who care about the comic books)He was tough, but no where near the magnitude of what his strengths could have been.

If I had the choice of waiting for the video, or paying 7 bucks to see it again, I know that I would wait. The hype was better than the movie was.

title: Not Fantastic, but FAR from horrible.
review: Reading all the horrible bashing reviews of Fantastic Four, i had low expectations of the movie. But i came out of the theater pleased none the less. This is not a groundbreaking, amazing CGI, blockbuster film, but its sure not crappy like its been made out to be. The film was very well cast, with the expect ion of Chris Evans who any good looking guy in Hollywood could have played. The film is cheesy at times but so is the story of the Fantastic Four so you get what you paid for. Could have had alittle more something something in it, but it didn't and it still works just fine. Not the best superhero film ever made, but FAR from the worst. Maybe a sequel will be alittle better directed and have what the first lacked. 7/10

title: More than okay, less than FANTASTIC
review:
You read me!!!

I went today with high expectation on the movie that turned out to be quite disappointing. Although, I am not a die-hard fan of fantastic four, I have been following movies based on MARVEL comics such as Spiderman, X-MEN, Daredevil, etc. And by far, this is one of the worst.

I find that the elements of the characters and the action are not as good as I expect to them to be. The plot is not as catchy or as interesting as movies such as XMEN and Spideman. Well, it is probably just me.

So, If you just want to watch a movie, this will be great! But, if you expect more out of it, it may really disappoint you!

title: I haven't seen this movie...
review: ...but I know enough about it that I have no desire to see it. All the bad press he movie seems to be getting only serves to confirm my lack of interest. For one thing, I know that it is not quite true to the comics. Not that that is a bad thing, necessarily, but making Dr. Doom a CEO is just lame, IMO. Should have just gone with the Mole Man and his giant subterranean monster in this film and left Doom for a sequel. I realize the thought was that Doom would've made a more exciting villain but if the end result is to dumb down the original, why bother? Dr. Doom is the Lex Luthor of the Marvel Universe but that doesn't mean he has to have the same profession.

title: The title of this movie should read: Chris Evans is HOT.
review:
I just saw this movie at a sneak preview last night. As far as comicbook movies go, this one was pretty shallow.

(Keep in mind that I don't read the comics, so I'm coming from the point of view of the audience segment not already familiar with the back story. And obviously the creators are looking to broaden their audience to include people like me as opposed to specifically addressing comic fans, so all you nerds getting your light sabers in a twist because there was some nuance I didn't catch, get a grip.) This movie had the feel of those movie sequels where all the returning characters mail it in with glib remarks instead of conveying any depth of emotion or intimacy, because you were supposed to "gotten" that in the previous movies.

In this movie, all these characters know each other, worked with each other, and in a couple cases, are related to each other and dated each other. So where's the chemistry? Sue and Reed act more like lab partners than pining lovers. Sue and Johnny are brother and sister, and you're supposed to get that connection because she tells him to grow up, and he jokes that he's going to be "scarred for life" when she strips to her underwear to be invisible. ClichÃ©d but still doesn't work. First of all, she's not hideous, sister or not. Second of all, she's in her underwear, not a gangbang video. What's the big deal?

Another thing is, except for Reed, I never got any impression that any of the other scientists were, well, smart. Much less brilliant. Where was the technobabble, the certifications and qualifications, the science talk? So, as far as comic book movies go, I'd say this one is the most mediocre. The acting is only okay, the character development is only okay, the action is only okay, the spec effects are only okay, and I get the impression that most of the connection made with the audience is through comic book references so that comicon nerds can feel comfortable that the characters are being represented accurately.

There is one saving grace to this movie, which I mentioned in the summary. Chris Evans is hot! Smoking hot! Get it? Get it? He's smoking hot because he catches fire, and also because he's a fine piece of man meat! Which you get to see, a LOT, because his clothes keep burning off! Because he's smoking hot!! Ha ha! Not only does it make for a continually amusing double entendre, (at least it did for me) it also makes for continually appreciable gratuitous semi-nudity. Whenever Chris Evans isn't running around in a skintight jumpsuit, he's running around half or mostly naked. In a movie world where Bo and Luke Duke got recast with Stiffler and Jackass, it's extremely refreshing to see that some directors still care enough about their female audience to include attractive actors and gratuitous male nudity. Thank you, Tim Story. It made your movie watchable.

(And thank YOU, Chris Evans. Keep up the good work!)

title: Story is proving himself to be a disappointing director
review:
Fantastic Four Reviewed by Sam Osborn

Rating: 2 out of 4

Director: Tim Story Cast: Michael Chiklis, Jessica Alba, Chris Evans, Julian McMahon, Ioan Gruffudd Screenplay: Michael France, Mark Frost, MPAA Classification: PG-13 (sequences of intense action, and some suggestive content)

There's so much giddy energy injected into Fantastic Four that it's difficult not to like. Despite so many missteps and problems, the film still manages to endear its audiences to the comic book hokey-ness that's absent from many of the new comic book to film adaptations. Point in fact, Batman Begins dropped the cartoon corniness for an affective grim surrealism. But Fantastic Four embraces the cheesy dialogue bubbles and uses them both to the film's advantage and to its disadvantage.

What's most frustrating when watching Fantastic Four is its absurd sense of pacing. For 90 minutes, director Tim Story develops his characters without much concern for the audience's excitement. We're treated to a single fight sequence in that entire 90 minute segment. Albeit, the sequence is amazing, but still, a bit more action couldn't hurt.

The film opens with failed corporate businessman Richard Reed (Ioan Gruffud) and his bodyguard Ben Grimm (Michael Chiklis) heading up to the top story of the Von Doom building in New York City. There they pitch their idea to Victor von Doom (Julian McMahon), the richest businessman in the world. Their theory one of a radioactive wave from space causing Earth's planetary evolution. Six weeks from now, another one of the waves will enter Earth's orbit. Reed would like to take a shuttle up to von Doom's space station and use its uniquely powerful shields to study the wave. Seeing it as a grand financial opportunity, von Doom bites and soon enough Reed and Doom's team are scooting around Victor's space station. The team includes Ben Grimm, Susan Storm (Jessica Alba), Victor's head of Genetic research and love interest, her brother Johnny (Chris Evans), a lover of extreme sports and former NASA pilot, Victor, and Richard. All is going well until unexplainable the wave closes in much faster than expected, catching the entire team by surprise. Not able to get the shields up in time, all the team members are exposed to the wave and consequently have their DNA strangely altered. Gradually, all their newfound superpowers are revealed. Reed is now Mr. Fantastic, with a rubber body. Susan is now The Invisible Girl, who also has the power of conjuring up strong force fields. Johnny is now The Human Torch, having the power to engulf himself in flames and somehow fly. Ben is now The Thing, made entirely out of rock. Lastly, Victor von Doom is secretly and slowly changing into a man made entirely of steel stronger than diamonds. When the former four decide to try and reverse the changes, Victor decides to use his power to take over the world. As if his name didn't give it away.

As I mentioned earlier, the desperately slow pace of the film puts a hamper on what could have been an epic comic book adventure. The screenplay strives to build three-dimensional characters, but leaves the dialogue to material we expect only from the little white dialogue bubbles in the comics. These work fine for comic books, but put to the actors the lines come out cheesy and ineffective. But the blame can't be dumped on the acting. Although none of the five main actors put up performances any more than acceptable, the material they have to work with is surely flawed.

However, when we do finally get to the action, it's simply stunning. Staying true to the long running comic book series, the film's action sequences utilize all the different abilities of the Fantastic Four. The action isn't minced into half-second shots as it was in the upcoming The Island and Christopher Nolan's Batman Begins, but given large scope, allowing us to witness it in all its glistening entirety. But the CGI work, although abundant, is hit and miss in quality. Some of the earlier shots, a space-ship docking shot in particular, are strangely poor. But work with Alba's invisibility and force-fields are quite eye-widening. There's a great scene where the four are dukin' it out with Doom on the streets of New York; Johnny lights himself to the point of "Supernova", creating a boiling hot explosion contained by a half-spherical semi-transparent force-field of Susan Storm. In scenes like these, where there's this great mix of beautiful art design and clever action choreography, Fantastic Four finally finds its feet.

It's a shame that throughout the rest of the film, the disappointing Dr. Doom and his evil scheming are little more than backdrops to the corny, one-dimensional character development Tim Story tries to create. Some of this lack of comic book violence can be attributed to the film's apparent "lightness." It's rumored that an early version of the screenplay would have garnered a PG rating. And today, a PG rating is almost as suicidal as an NC-17. PG-13 reigns king over the summer box office. But even with a PG-13 rating, Fantastic Four still feels somehow light. Dr. Doom isn't all that scary, about on par with Spiderman's Green Goblin. And substituting for action sequences are lame extreme sports endeavors with Johnny Storm. Johnny's one of the more entertaining aspects of the film, but snowboarding and motorcycles rarely live up to superpower combat on the city's streets.

I feel let down by Fantastic Four. Tim Story is proving himself to be a disappointing director, coming off of Taxi last year and following it up with this high-profile letdown. The film leaves much open-ended material for a sequel. So lets hope another screenwriter and a drastically different director get behind the helm of our next adventure with the Fantastic Four.

title: Parents...A Movie you can take your kids to see without...
review: worrying about the usual sexual content (except a brief appearance of Jessica Alba in her underwear which could be looked upon like a bikini by the pool) from prime-time TV or drug references from prime-time TV or profanity from prime-time TV...(God, I hate TV). I think that says a lot about an enjoyable movie that i didn't have to worry about taking my 10 yr. old daughter to see. The critics and action starving comic book affectionados are shredding this movie because they're comparing it to the best comic movies. Don't expect a Spiderman, X-Men or Batman caliber of movie...you won't get it. But, if you want to spend some priceless time with your kids with this FUN movie, then I whole-heartedly recommend it. I can almost guarantee the sequel will TRULY be SUPER FANTASTIC!

title: The critics are wrong
review: Every now and again, there's a movie that comes out that all the critics rip apart but then the standard viewers really enjoy it. Fantastic Four is certainly one of those instances. I saw it expecting nothing outstanding from it because with all due respect the F4 have never been the coolest team and I've always thought of them as somewhat tacky actually. That's sort of just what they are, so I wasn't expecting a different spin on the X-Men films, I was expecting a light-hearted origin story basically, and that's what I got. I was never bored, even when there was very little action going on the 4 were still using their powers and it was cool to watch. In fact, this movie was supposed to be comical in a way, and it really was. You saw them come to grips with their powers as they have difficulty getting along with one another, but in the end they come together like a family and cover each other's backs when duty called for it. If there wasn't enough action for some viewers, it can at least be said that this was certainly an entertaining movie, and I'm curious to see future films and how some villains are revamped to be more suitable for the big screen.

title: Fantastic? Maybe
review:
Now I must say that Tim Story did a fairly good job of translating the original comic book into a movie. The casting was done very well, with maybe the exception of Jessica Alba. Chris Evans, Mike Chiklis, and Ioan Gruffudd were excellent choices for the heroes.

If you haven't seen the movie and aren't a big FF fan, then I have some advice. You shouldn't go into it looking for an average or cliché superhero movie. Of course, the movie will have the cliché elements of cheesy catchphrases (thanks to Stan Lee), but it's Marvel! This movie can be compared most to Spider Man; you have five characters not interested in superpowers and then they get them by accident. But, unlike Spider Man, they spend a good part of their time trying to find a "cure" for their powers. Does this take away from the movie experience? Only if you're looking for an action superhero movie with lots of fight scenes and mindless "clobbering." No, my friends, because this movie actually has a story. The emotional center is Ben Grimm/The Thing, and you can't help but feel sorry for the guy. These are four good friends that want to be friends (well, for the most part). Grimm WANTS to be cured and is an emotional wreck.

I'll try not to spoil much, but go into this movie without great expectations and you should come out fairly pleased. I would give the movie a 7.8, because of some logistical things (you'll know when you see it), but I still loved it. If you're a big FF fan like myself, I can say that you won't be disappointed (much).

title: Fantastic? That's debatable *Spoilers*
review:
I'm giving this movie a high rating because I really enjoyed it. I think the cast were fine actors working with the very minimum of a script.

The truth is there is some storyline of Dr. Doom going insane after the loss of his company thanks to Reed's failed experiment and trying to take down the fantastic four as revenge. It's a weak storyline, but still there.

Now Marvel has always had their heroes being struggling, not enjoying the superhero business and the storyline has followed through here with the "Thing" who looses his fiancé because of his transformation. The others are having problems between themselves (old feelings coming back yadda yadda) My only real advice here is that if you want a dark "thinking" movie, go see Batman Begins, however if you want a fun summer movie that focuses on action and some interestingly placed comedy then Fantastic Four is for you.

Hopefully if they make a sequel, now that they have the basics (introducion of powers, etc.) covered they can make a movie more friendly to critics.

title: Critics' reaction shows how far we have come...
review:
...in producing quality adaptations of low-brow material(comic books). After the 2 Spider-man movies, X-Men, Sin City, and now Batman Begins, the bar has been raised on what to expect. Also, FF was made on a very short time line, with an unheralded director, and a B-list cast. In spite of these limitations, the movie I saw was very enjoyable, and it moved quickly.

***********spoilers********************

Now, this is far from the ideal FF movie. The problem is, how to use cinema shorthand to tell a story that has been 44 years in developing. Thus, we get a wife for Ben, whose only purpose is to demonstrate how tragic the Thing's transformation is. Doom has been included in the space flight in order to give him 1) reason to hate the FF, and 2) cause for homicidal insanity. Of course, what makes Doom in the comics so evil is the fact that he is perfectly sane, but cripplingly arrogant and proud, with blind lust for power. If the franchise goes for one or two more movies, the ending of "FF" indicates that we may next see Doom in a form much closer to his comic self. Man, would it be great to see Ben and Johnny wading into an army of Doom-bots!

Yet, we need to acknowledge what "FF" gets right. The costumes, the powers, the banter between the team members, and 4/5 of the cast are all about as good as one could hope for. Johnny is just perfect! Updating him to an extreme sports junkie is a great way to bring out his impulsive, fearless nature. The Torch is my absolute favorite part of "FF". Also, the scenes of Ben trying to live in a world too fragile for him are great! His interplay with Johnny is dead-on, and not overdone. Reed comes off too wimpy in the beginning, but he has the dedication and concern for others that makes him a strong heroic figure. The scenes of him working around the clock in his lab, complete with 2 days beard, are taken directly from numerous FF stories. His tussle with Ben is priceless, he really is Mr. Fantastic. Sue is radically changed, like Doom. Alba's casting is, for me, the weakest part of the movie. She was obviously cast for her name recognition and her ability to look quite fetching in a suit of unstable molecules. On the plus side, her Sue is a strong character, and she assumes the leadership role early on, when Reed is just befuddled. She is simply too young for this role.

**************end spoilers************************

Another IMDb user commented that what is missing is the sense of wonder in the FF books, the feeling that we were going somewhere we had never been before. Fantastic Four, the comic, embraces the wonders of technology as a way to better ourselves, a force for good in the world. That kind of innocent optimism is somewhat out of style now.

When I heard all the negatives prior to release, I lowered my expectations for the "FF". I am a total Marvel freak, I started reading the comics in 1966, and I have all the action figures. I realize that big-budget movies involve compromise, and "FF" is not immune. The producers, in an attempt to draw the teen target audience, included some gags and music that will not age well. "FF" lacks the timeless quality of "Spider-man", the master template for good superhero movies. The changes to Doom especially have upset many of the comics fans. Yet, would this movie ever have been made without these concessions? The Fantastic Four is not a pop culture icon like Batman or Spider-man, recognizable to all but the extreme media-deprived. Overall, though, "FF" is a good summer movie, just not the best possible FF adaptation. I can live with that.

title: Dr DOOM destroyed
review:
Dear Pals, Does anyone thought the movie was quite alright, but... became seriously disappointed with Dr. Doom ??? C'mon... the "REAL" Dr. Doom would be far more interesting than that "Iron man like" character...

3 facts, that in my opinion could be avoided and would make the movie better: 1 - Dr. Doom, should not be involved in the cosmic ray transformation... neither in the "skin becoming iron" process... and neither in becoming a super-strenght villain; 2- Why wouldn't the film makers did not make him a super-genius kind of villain, and used him to attack New York with a robotic army in a closer way of "ruling" the world character ? 3- Why they did not show him creating his armor or even creating his mask, after the incident where he became deformed ? Just a few "simple" facts... that could make the movie better.

In my opinion a good "popcorn" movie... from 0 to 10... I give it a 7.

title: Solid fun but falls a bit short.
review:
I'm in my mid-fifties and a huge fan of comic book movies. I love it when Hollywood brings my favorite comic book heroes to life on the big screen using state of the art technology to convince me of their reality.

F4 succeeds in the CGI and effects department. I was somewhat concerned when I learned that "The Thing" would be done with a prosthetic suit instead of CGI, but I think it was pulled off nicely due, in no small part, to Michael Chiklis' characterization.

Ioan Gruffudd as Reed Richarsds was visually acceptable, but was a bit of a milquetoast compared to the character in the comic book.

Jessica Alba as Sue Storm I found to be more than acceptable. Perhaps a bit too buff compared to the comic's character, I nonetheless found Alba's interpretation of Sue Storm to be exotic and endearing. If a franchise develops, I hope Alba returns as The Invisible Girl.

Chris Evans may have been born to play Johnny Storm. He was perfect as the 'cocky young guy' and brings to mind Chris O'Donnell's performance as "Robin" in the Batman franchise. Evans obviously had a lot of fun playing the character and should definitely be tapped to return if a franchise develops.

Julian McMahon as Dr. Doom was respectable, and I would not balk should he return in the role. However...

Where this film fell short for me was the story itself. The first part of the film did well in presenting the basic facts of how the Fantastic Four gained their abilities. And I even understand that for a 'first of the franchise' type of film that certain elements of each of the characters had to be presented in a way that remained true to the comic. Still, though, when the film reached it's grand finale battle with Dr. Doom, I found myself thinking "Is that it?" And it was...the end of the film, and I felt let down.

While I felt that all of the basics of the story had been presented and the SFX were on mark, the story fell short of creating a truly ominous villain in the character of Dr. Doom. This was not the actor's fault. The blame is squarely on the director and screenwriter. Dr. Doom was far too easy to thwart! Whenever Victor Von Doom was on the screen there was no sense of foreboding and evil. In the comics I remember Dr. Doom as a nearly omnipotent force of evil. In this film Dr. Doom is just a man with a few quirks. And he was far, far, far too easy to thwart! Without a truly ominous and evil Dr. Doom the characters of the Fantastic Four had no credible foil to play against, and thus their characterizations were diminished.

Still, though certainly not a high-water mark in the genre, Fantastic Four is solid entertainment and a lot of fun. But, should the franchise continue, I think the director would be wise to first become a TRUE fan of the original comic, second watch and study every film by Sam Peckinpah, Steven Spielberg and John Frankenheimer, and third forget about ratings, the 'kiddies' and family fare, but instead make a film that tells a knuckle-whitening story as do the comics.

There have been many films where it is easy to say that the SFX did not serve the story. In this film the story did not serve the SFX.

5 stars out of 10 for SFX, and Jessica Alba. Add two stars for Michael Chiklis as "The Thing". Verdict: 7 out of 10 stars.

title: Actually not bad!
review: I'm a pretty battle hardened movie goer, especially when it comes to Sci-fi, and this movie really isn't as bad as the reviews would lead you to believe. One review said it was 'Catwoman bad'; I read that a few days ago reading and I got worried! Well much to my surprise, it was actually a pretty decent comic book movie. It wasn't Spidey 2 or X2 quality, but it was certainly not Catwoman bad or Daredevil bad or even Hulk bad. Here's what I liked: The Thing - Mike Chiklis really brought this character to life. From the moment he became 'Thing', and you heard his voice, he owned the role. Almost like Hugh did with Wolverine. Human Torch - this kid was pretty funny and provided much of the comic relief. The actor actually had good timing and deadpan. His taunting relationship with 'Thing' was just like the comics, they're always fighting. Doom - he was pretty cool too, a little to cliché, but OK, I'll roll with it. They got his look dead-on though. Straight out the comic book. Here's what as OK: Invisible Girl - yeah, she's hot. but unfortunately she wasn't as convincing as Thing and Torch. Some of her dialogue was really bad. But she's real cute. The Special effects - not bad but not amazing either. You could tell that there were budget constraints that limited some of the effects. The story - pretty true to the comic but unfortunately it had some ridiculous scenarios to bring it down. What I didn't like: Mr. Fantastic - I thought he was miscast and not very convincing. A pretty mediocre genius if you ask me, and really unconfident. Jeff Goldbloom may have been a better choice for this role. Overall a really decent comic movie!

title: Certainly Entertaining, but Nothing... Fantastic
review: Although I thoroughly enjoyed "Fantastic Four" and found it quite entertaining, it is definitely not spectacular. The movie begins with Reed Richards (Ioan Gruffudd), the brilliant, yet out of luck (and money), scientist, and his best friend, Ben Grimm (Michael Chiklis-The Shield), astronaut and pilot. Their dream: to study the effects of a cosmic storm on human DNA in order to learn more about the basic make-up of human beings, and possibly find cures for the world's most destructive diseases. However, Reed must seek funding from former MIT rival (and current industrial millionaire) Victor Von Doom (Julian McMahon-Nip/ Tuck and Charmed), who is also "dating" Reed's former love, the brilliant and beautiful Susan Storm (Jessica Alba-Honey). Also on the trip is Sue's younger brother, hothead pilot Johnny Storm (Chris Evans-Cellular and The Perfect Score), who also happens to be a self-centered attention-seeker (and really hot... no pun intended). But as they near the completion of their mission, it becomes apparent that Reed has miscalculated the speed of the storm, and the crew has minutes to get Ben back into the ship and activate the shields. This they fail to do, and Ben, Reed, Sue, and Johnny are all exposed to mutating radiation. When they wake up in quarantine days later, they find they have transformed into superheroes. Reed, the leader of the group, has become "Mr. Fantastic", with the ability to stretch and contort his limbs like rubber. Sue, now "The Invisible Girl", has the ability to become invisible, as well as bend and deflect light. Ben (who has gone through the most dramatic change) becomes a big rock-like... thing with superhuman strength, and is aptly named "The Thing". Finally, Johnny has become "The Human Torch", and can engulf himself in flames and reach dizzying heat (like the heat of a supernova). The four team together to form "The Fantastic Four", and battle the evil Victor, now Dr. Doom, who was also transformed by the storm into a metallic villain. Will the superheroes defeat the bad-guy? You figure it out. However, the ending does leave room for a sequel... because in Hollywood, there's always gotta be a sequel (just look at Garfield 2 and Cheaper By the Dozen 2). All in all, a good, highly entertaining movie, which, although it fails to thoroughly impress, at least made me want to write a review.

title: Another lost opportunity....
review:
Okay, I saw this movie tonight and it was fairly enjoyable, but nowhere near great. (I'd like to give it a 6.5/10, but since we have to choose whole numbers, I went ahead and gave it a 7.) Marvel is blowing it big time. With every mediocre movie, they are further "expending" their most valuable characters. They've now used up X-Men, the Hulk, Fantastic Four, Daredevil, Elektra, the Punisher, Man-Thing, Spider-Man, and more to come, like Ghost Rider. With the exceptions of X-Men and Spider-Man, the movies ranged from absolutely terrible (Man-Thing) to various shades of okay/decent (Punisher, Hulk, Daredevil, Elektra). Avi Arad of Marvel just doesn't seem to be getting it--once these characters are used, they're done for at least several years! Not every mediocre comic book movie gets revitalized like the Batman franchise. More likely, they'll fade away and be forgotten, and the more often it happens, the less Hollywood will want to create comic book movies. Marvel should know this! So why are they letting mediocre and little known directors/talent work on their their flagship characters? Where is Stone, Cameron, Howard, Spielberg, Singer (okay, he did do two X-Men movies) and the other A-list talent that should be spearheading the biggest comic book movies? And why the heck would Marvel put a great brand like Fantastic Four in the hands of a guy that did "Barbershop" and not much else? Sadly, I just don't get it.

So from all that, I'm sure you can tell I wasn't overly impressed. It was an okay action flick and decent special effects. The acting seemed wooden at times, and some scenes were either edited heavily or just didn't make much sense. The actors gave it a valiant try, but at least two of them weren't even close to up to snuff. The writing was cheesy and not nearly serious enough for the epic this movie should have been. And of course, we had the obligatory change of events from the comic to the screen. You know what I mean--when the Hollywood writer/director decides that the comic story was "silly" and adds his own ideas into the character's origin, thus alienating many comic readers by ignoring comic book cannon. This doesn't bother me IF the change is really necessary or adds to the story, but too often it's an arbitrary change (i.e. changing the Hulk's name from "David" to "Bruce" in the TV show) that really adds nothing to the story. Also, a few cheesy lines are fine, but this movie went overboard. My personal (un)favorite for "Absolute Worst Line in this Movie(tm)" was the Johnny Storm one-liner: "You're Hot", "Why thank you--so are you!" Ugh. How lame.

I do admit that Chris Evans, who I wasn't familiar with until now, did an excellent job as the Human Torch, but it wasn't enough to turn this movie around.

If I had to briefly describe the movie's faults, I'd say it's a combination of mediocre acting and mediocre writing/directing. Avi, please start demanding top talent for your movies. I promise you it will pay off!

title: It was a good, fun movie, not great but about what I wanted
review:
I'm amazed at all the bashing this movie is receiving. Some people say that movie company posted some ringer comments. That may be true, but from what I read, it looks to me like the competition has posted some ringers of their own to bash it.

Reading a lot of the comments, I get the feeling people are expecting too much from this movie. Batman Begins is a different order of movie. I expected serious and dark there. Here I was looking for and found light and fun. I enjoyed both movies. Obviously Batman Begins was the better movie but it was not light fare either.

A little less of Johnny Storm might have improved this a bit. But in general Chris Evans did a very nice job of portraying this character. He was annoying but he was meant to be. I enjoyed the way he enjoyed his talent.

Michael Chiklis did a great job as the Thing. The one that gave me the most trouble is Julian McMahon as Dr. Doom. IT didn't come across well.

In summary, my wife and I went out to see a light, fun movie and got exactly what we were looking for. If that is what you want, I recommend it. If you are looking for the next Best Film or Best Action film, stay home because there is nothing for you in the theaters now and, I suspect, there never will be.

title: Fantastic to an extent - Vic Mackey
review: It's just one thing, Vik Mackey as THE THING. He talked just like Vik Mackey which was really cool. There was no character development AT ALL. The entire traffic scene in which pure carnage was unleashed, was ALL THE FAULT of The Thing. He should have let that guy JUMP to his death. And then there is Dr. Doom, or shall I say, Doctor Van Doom. What kind of weirdo CEO has the last name of DOOM? I guess a Marvel Comic Book character does, that's who!! And what was the deal with the Invisible Girl? She has a force field that bent light? That was odd. This movie was so so. What you see is what you get. Tedd Gilbert's wife is expecting a child. I wonder if this child will grow to like The Fantastic Four?

title: Actually like your regular, average, dopey comic book.
review: There are your good, bad and average comic books. Just like your good, bad and average movies. I have been reading the Fantastic Four since the beginning (actually since Spiderman, so I missed the first few issues), and while this movie is not great, it does evoke a lot of the confused spirit of the first few years of the comic book. Let's face it: there is nothing wrong with this movie a better director could not have fixed. But for what it is, it does it pretty well. I had a feeling as I left the theater that the producers decided to go a different way with this movie (as opposed to the great Spiderman and X-Men films). To make a light, carefree presentation that does not violate the inherent intent of the book; and speaking as one who has loved and followed the book since the early 1960's, I think that was accomplished. If they were trying to give the public a presentation of a typical average, dopey comic book, I think they were successful. Not every comic book movie has to be a great movie (think Batman Begins, or Spiderman 2), and there is room for a basic entertaining movie that is faithful to the core material that comes off slight.

title: it was good
review:
in my opinion, i thought it was really good. the funny parts were both humorous and cute and the overall plot was good. i haven't been caught up with the fantastic four since i was about 10 but i think the movie very well corresponded with the comic.

i do agree that the graphics part of mr. fantastic stretching himself to open the door was really fake but i still thought it was really good.

and the part about sue storm and reed richards not being super old in this movie was all because this movie was just telling about the beginning of the fantastic four. if you notice in the movie, reed and sue weren't even married yet.

title: Not fantastic, but a pretty good movie nonetheless.
review: This movie was rather good and it was a bit light and not as serious as say "Batman Begins". Hey these are the Fantastic Four though and not the Dark Knight, their name suggests they are going to be a bit less serious. Could have been more action, but it had its comic moments that made up for the lack of action. All the Fantastic Four actors were great so now it is time for my number one major gripe of the film. Doctor Doom was portrayed completely wrong, I did not let it ruin the film for me, but I really did not think the actor was right and I also don't think it would have been all that hard to get his origin correct. He never had any powers in the comic book, he was simply a brilliant scientist and dabbler in magic who blamed Reed for an accident that left him permanently scarred. He created a powerful armor to combat the Fantastic Four and is one of the best Marvel villains there is even fighting the likes of Spider-man. Here he also comes into contact with the cosmic rays and the armor he built in the comic just starts to form on him. They make mention of his homeland, but I am not sure if he is the leader. To tell ya the truth I feel Arnold Schwarzenegger would have been the perfect Doom, but then I am not a movie maker so what do I know. Other than that for the most part I liked the movie. People have been complaining about the effects, but I thought they were pretty good, not top notch, but then this movie was not given an unlimited budget. Probably had something to do with the fact the Hulk underachieved, I doubt they were going to give this movie over a 150 million budget when the slightly more known Hulk didn't pull in all that much. Five or six years ago though, had this movie come out the effects would have been considered top notch, just not by todays standards. The Thing was great, it did look like rock, and all the others had their powers working good too. The fight with Doom could have been a bit longer, but this is an origin tale so they have to establish characters first. So in the end do not expect to be blown out of the water, but do expect a more basic summer popcorn flick.

title: A Good Saturday Matinée Movie
review: This was a good time at the movies. I wished the exciting bits could have been more exciting, but I have even less imagination than the screen writers, so I don't know how. All the Fantastic Four characters were well written, but developing four superheroes and a villain must be technically demanding. I wished for more from each of them, especially, Jessica Alba. This is the second time that she played a character who could have been naked and was not. That gripes my ass. What gripes it even more is gratuitous negritude, apparently, Hollywood's compulsory theme. Movies of this era will seem deformed, ridiculous, and antiquated. I want the people of the future to know that were those of us here in the past who realized that the trend was desperate and stupid. We contained our exasperation with idiots in charge as best we could.

title: As a person with at least a little knowledge of comics...
review: This movie was NO WHERE NEAR as bad as you people on this board claim. Me being a person with no complete knowledge of the Fantastic Four, actually they were never exactly my favorites from Marvel, I really enjoyed this movie. Everyone else in the theater seemed to find it great too. After being on these boards and hearing this movie being bashed left and right, I was expecting it to be horrible or at least okay, nothing special. I was pleasantly surprised. This movie had a lot of humor in it, which seemed to keep me and the rest of the audience entertained. Although Doom might have been weak at times, or at least not up to the comics, I was impressed about how well Gruffudd, Alba, Evans and Chiklis were together as the Fantastic Four. Good altogether "chemistry" or whatever you wanna call it between them. Sometimes at each others throats then friends the next. This is no masterpiece of a movie, but a good summer blockbuster.

title: Impressive...But Not Impressive Enough.
review: I walked into the theater with medium expectations...and i didn't receive much, The Special Effects were impressive and well done. But The Story was dodgy and could have had a lot more work...i also thought this film was sort of rushed.....the character i liked the most would be Doom or in the comics he is called Dr Doom, the villain is always the most appealing character in superhero movies to me...impressive more and enjoyable enough, probably a bit to much comedy and not enough action...but it worth getting on DVD. I Give this Movie about a 6 out of 10 for most of the special effects, and the story was pretty decent but as i said could have been much better.

title: No "Batman Begins"... but mostly solid stuff
review:
Well, I just returned from watching "Fantastic Four"... and I think the mixed reviews it's been getting are pretty justified. For those of you who aren't aware, "Four" is about four (duh) friends whose genetic material is changed by a radioactive cloud on a trip to outer space, and their subsequent evolution into the well-known superhero team. Sounds like a fairly interesting story, right? It would be, but "Fantastic Four" falls short in the one area that gave "Spiderman" and "Batman Begins" such high praise-- character depth. Unlike many reviewers, I don't think the problem lies with the actors; the script was terrible. The screenwriter's one-liners and dumb jokes seem more fitting for a bland teen movie, and there is hardly any room for growth.

In fact, the acting is fairly good. Chris Evans (as Johnny Storm) is probably the funniest part of the movie; all of the good dialogue went to him, and his antics are, for the most part, in line with what I think the comic's creators had in mind. Michael Chiklis (as Ben Grimm) deserves a lot of praise not only for getting into that Thing suit every day, but for giving the gentle giant a depth that none of the other characters reaches. Ioan Gruffudd's Reed Richards is appropriately stiff, painfully geeky, and as a result isn't very likable, but he's a fine young actor, and I give him props for remaining true to the character. Jessica Alba's interpretation of Sue Storm was less than satisfying; however, her lines were by far the worst. Julian McMahon played a pretty flat, one-sided Victor Von Doom, but with a self-explanatory name like that, the creators were already condemning him to the one-sided evil villain subgroup.

Otherwise, if you're looking for something entertaining to watch on a hot summer's day (or want a good smash-em-up superhero film to take the kids to that isn't as dark as the newest "Batman" installment), "Fantastic Four" delivers. If you're looking for an interesting movie that will make you think, I'd advise you to look elsewhere.

title: not as terrible as i thought it would be
review:
I'm not a fan of the Fantastic Four going into this movie. I never really like the characters. I'm more of a Spider-man/Batman fan. I went into this movie with a 2 star expectation (The same grade I gave to the 1993 version). I was surprised. I was able to sit through the movie and I was somewhat entertained.

My favorite aspect of this movie was Chiklis (The Thing) was entertaining to watch, especially compared to the other cast. Alba could have done a better job acting.

The main problem I have with this movie is with Doom. We have to sit through this movie and see his progression into evil, and then we experience the disappointing villain and ending which is essential in every comic book movie.

I'm sure the pre-teens will love this movie. There is some funny moments and there is some annoying moments with Johnny Storm (unless you're 8 years old).

If you're a comic-book fan then this is a rental that will keep you entertained. It's not quite a guilty pleasure (7 stars) but I was able to sit through this one without having to check my watch every five minutes.

title: Pretty OK
review: This adaptation of a Marvel Comic mainstay just passes muster. It got the basic characters and humorous mood right, has a good cast, and I hope we get some sequels, which should be better. There had to have been some major editing around one of the climactic scenes (when Reed, Sue, and Johnny first see Ben as the Thing), because none of it made any narrative or emotional sense. That scene was just badly done. But I'm just glad this wasn't so bad (like the Hulk) that any hope of sequels was destroyed. This could be a fun series with this cast. This take on the FF is sexy, fun, and cool. So what if it's dumb fun? I hope this Four gets to fight another day, to take on Galactus and meet the Silver Surfer.

title: 'Fantastic 4' a splashier, wittier addition to the genre
review:
Fantastic 4 When an experimental space voyage goes awry, four people are changed by cosmic rays. Reed Richards, inventor and leader of the group gains the ability to stretch his body, and takes the name, Mr. Fantastic. His girlfriend, Sue Storm, gains the ability to turn invisible and create force fields, calling herself the Invisible Woman. Her younger brother Johnny Storm gains the ability to control fire, including covering his own body with flame, becoming the Human Torch. Pilot Ben Grimm is turned into a super-strong rock creature calling himself Thing. Together, they use their unique powers to explore the strange aspects of the world, and to foil the evil plans of Doctor Doom.

Who would have thought making a marvel comic book movie colorful and filled with humor? 'Fantastic 4', the latest addition in the comic book to movie adaptation, is one of the better ones of the genre. It's much more splashy and light then the darker ones, like Batman Begins, and it has more humor then it has any right to. The actors have a lot of charisma, and fit their roles well. Chris Evans plays his role with ease, as the only one excited about having these powers, and using them to get money and babes. The film's entertaining enough to keep out attention: fast, sleek and, yes, even vivid at times.

My few problems with the film are as follows: It's cheesy at times, and there's a lapse of time when they have no villain at all, and they're just trying to get a deeper understanding of their powers, which eventually runs a little thin. But there's enough positive points to outshine the negative points. So, if you walk into the theater expecting 'SpiderMan2', you might be a little disappointed. But if you walk in going with the film's silly charm, you'll be surprised. Trust me, it's no 'SpiderMan2', but it's certainly no 'Daredevil' either.

3.25 from 4 PG13- action sequences and some language/suggestive content.

title: It Ain't Spiderman!
review:
The Fantastic Four is pure dumb fun, a light summer confection. It is not in the same league as the aforementioned Spiderman, the first two Batman movies or the recently released Batman Begins. Nonetheless, it can be enjoyed for what it is--a family friendly popcorn flick.

The film starts somewhat slowly. It could almost be forgiven if it were due to exposition, however, this was not the case. Instead we were introduced to main characters with but sketchy information about their pasts together. It is a movie that requires that work your imagination a bit to fill in the blanks. Then, shortly after the catastrophic event that changes these characters for life, we are given a quick cut that feels like someone forgot a reel. One minute we are in outer space, and in the next we are back on earth in a hospital setting. It is jarring. Happily, things pick up form there and fun ensues.

The portrayals of the Human Torch and The Thing are the best parts of the film. The two of them provide the majority of the humor and action for the final two thirds of the film. Other half of the quartet don't quite click as well. Reed Richards, Mr. Fantastic and Sue Storm, The Invisible Girl, don't quite have the chemistry. The romance between them seems a bit forced. Only the quickly unfolding relationship between Ben Grimm (The Thing) and the blind Alicia appears more unlikely. This is the first of a three movie deal--an origin film. Hopefully, they will do more in the other two films. The pieces are here to build a very good film franchise.

I'm ready for the next one.
